Award.AwardTitle: Convergence Accelerator Phase I (RAISE): Preparing the Future Workforce of Architecture, Engineering, and Construction for Robotic Automation Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.

The broader impact/potential benefits of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project will address a crucial national problem by preparing the nation's workers and businesses in the Architecture, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industries for an increasingly automated future workplace. This convergent research and development project involves researchers in architecture, construction, engineering, computer science, STEM education and economic development, as well as industry collaborators from the robotics, architecture, engineering, construction and software industries. Its Phase 1 deliverables will benefit businesses, workers and professionals in the AEC industry cluster, as well as regional and national economic development policy. Phase 1 provides the platform for critical solutions: maximizing employment opportunity, minimizing job displacement, and improving national economic competitiveness in the AEC industries. Improving AEC industry performance also promises solutions leading to a more energy efficient and sustainable built environment.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase I project will contribute to research and application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and immersive virtual environments in education as well as examining economic impacts of automation technology adoption in the AEC industries. The rapid adoption of AI and automation promises new employment and business opportunities, but will also create job displacement and business disruption. The Project's Phase 1 research objectives are to develop 1) a prototype interactive virtual reality robotics training and educational software package, and 2) a new model to measure the economic impact of automation adoption. Phase 1 will provide a platform for an immersive virtual software to teach new skills, improve process workflows, and increase efficiency in the AEC industries. Integrating advanced technologies including Reinforcement Learning, Computer Vision, Augmented and Virtual Reality, the project will advance methods of remote and on-site training for a large segment of employees in the AEC industries. By applying STEM learning strategies, the project will contribute to understanding how people learn in technology rich environments and bridge the gap between technology advancement and application to practice. The Project's economic analysis will utilize a "bottom-up" approach to estimating the employment impacts resulting from the adoption of AI and robotics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The global economy is being rapidly reshaped by robots with dexterity, visual perception, speed, and strength. This intense focus on creating new technologies is bringing significant changes to job markets, requiring new workforce training in various professions and industry sectors. Therefore, preparing the workforce for an automation-driven economy is imperative.

Like many fields, robotics automation is transforming jobs in the building industry (Architecture, Engineering, and Construction sectors). This industry which accounts for one-eighth of the national GDP, drives the design, construction, and operation of the built environment- activities that impact almost every industry, trade, labor and employment market across the nation.

Our project, the Robotics Academy, is a cloud-based training platform designed to support the building industry workforce for transitioning to the robotics and automation economy of the future. Using advances in Cloud Computing, Artificial Intelligence (AI), Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR), the project aims to create a personalized and engaging training tool for developing skills for operating and innovating with industrial robots.

The project goal was to research and develop a plan for the Robotics Academy based on the following objectives: 1) Defining the training needs of the building industry for robotics automation, 2) Leveraging advances in technology to develop a personalized training tool which is tailored for different learning abilities and past experiences of the workforce,3) develop a knowledge network to support innovation in new technologies and automated building design and construction. The project outcomes include:

Interviews and Industry Summit: To understand the training needs and interests of the building industry, we conducted an industry summit and interviewed automation engineers, software developers, roboticists, designers, educators, and system integrators. Our findings indicated that robotic automation applications are rapidly increasing while workers equipped with technical proficiency remain low. Both employers and employees reported a lack of adequate access to robotic technology training and a lack of standardization for automation tools and programming procedures. 

Curriculum Design: We studied existing building industry and robotics courses, consulted with STEM curriculum developers, and worked with AI experts. Our research resulted in a curriculum with several focus areas, including fundamentals of operating industrial robotic arms; safety protocols and industry safety standards; computational thinking for robotics processes; end of arm tooling; and platform-specific programming for robotics. We designed and tested three pilot courses which allowed us to identify curriculum areas best suited for delivering robotics lessons in VR.

Software Requirements Analysis Document: We developed a detailed description of the software platform functionalities, the reasons for its development, its extent, and the context. This document is which is developed to expedite software development, details the purpose of the AI curated content, user data collection methods, learning scenarios, and use cases.

Prototypes: To test our curriculum and understand the affordances of VR and AR for training, we developed several simulations prototypes based on our findings from interviews and the industry summit. We identified and developed a working prototype with two introductory lessons for testing. Our goal was to evaluate the simulation workflow, translate the curriculum into interactive training, and collect data from learners.

Economics, Industry, and Business Analysis: The economics team completed 1) a detailed analysis of the AEC industry cluster, 2) modular and prefabricated construction adoption patterns, 3) a survey of representatives from construction firms in the manufactured housing industry, and 4) follow-up interviews with key manufactured construction businesses. We learned that extremely slow construction industry technology adoption places the US economy at risk. The nation?s construction industry must dramatically improve its productivity to meet critical national needs. Automated modular and prefabricated construction of buildings is the future, but represents only 4% of the current US construction industry, the majority of which simply builds using traditional onsite construction techniques.  The move to more automated engineering, design and construction could have severely disruptive impacts on the AEC cluster. 98% of all businesses in construction employ 20 people or less and as much as 40% of the current jobs in construction could be impacted. Our model of future job formation indicates that even with a 600% increase in labor productivity, made possible by a large industry shift to manufactured construction, rapid national demand could result in a net addition of new jobs. However, jobs will change dramatically. Businesses will need workers with a mix of construction, manufacturing, and machine operating skills that are very different from today?s construction trade skills.

This project will have far reaching impacts across research, academia, and the building industry by 1) providing a detailed analysis of the implications of robotic automation on the economy, 2) articulating the training needs of the building industry, 3) demonstrating innovative integration of advanced technologies for developing personalized learning environment for training, and 4) contributing to knowledge about how people learn in technology rich environments.
